message_1:
Given a smooth projective variety $X$ of dimension $n$ with a Hodge diamond 
$$
\begin{matrix}
&& h^{0,n} &&\\
& & \vdots & \\
h^{n,0} & & h^{n,n} & & h^{0,n}\\
& & \vdots &\\
&& h^{0,n} &&
\end{matrix}
$$
such that $h^{p,q} = 0$ if $p > n$ or $q > n$, prove that $\sum_{p=0}^{n}(-1)^p h^{p,p}$ is equal to the Euler characteristic $\chi(X)$. 

Consider the variety $X$ in $\mathbb{P}^2$ defined as the intersection of two quadrics: 
$$
X = \lbrace [x:y:z] \in \mathbb{P}^2 \ | \ x^2 + yz = 0, xy + z^2 = 0 \rbrace. 
$$
Find the Hodge diamond of $X$ and compute the Euler characteristic of $X$.
message_2:
To prove that $\sum_{p=0}^{n}(-1)^p h^{p,p}$ is equal to the Euler characteristic $\chi(X)$, we first recall the definition of the Euler characteristic for a smooth projective variety $X$ of dimension $n$:

$$\chi(X) = \sum_{i=0}^{2n} (-1)^i h^i(X),$$

where $h^i(X) = \dim H^i(X, \mathcal{O}_X)$ are the dimensions of the cohomology groups of the structure sheaf $\mathcal{O}_X$. By the Hodge decomposition theorem, we have

$$H^i(X, \mathcal{O}_X) \cong \bigoplus_{p+q=i} H^{p,q}(X).$$

Therefore, we can rewrite the Euler characteristic as

$$\chi(X) = \sum_{i=0}^{2n} (-1)^i \sum_{p+q=i} h^{p,q}.$$

Now, we want to show that this is equal to $\sum_{p=0}^{n}(-1)^p h^{p,p}$. To do this, we first notice that the terms with $p \neq q$ in the double sum will cancel out due to the symmetry of the Hodge diamond, i.e., $h^{p,q} = h^{q,p}$. Thus, we are left with

$$\chi(X) = \sum_{p=0}^{n} (-1)^p h^{p,p}.$$

Now, let's find the Hodge diamond of $X$ and compute the Euler characteristic of $X$. Since $X$ is a complete intersection of two quadrics in $\mathbb{P}^2$, it is a curve of genus $g = (2-1)(2-1)/2 = 1$. The Hodge diamond of a curve of genus $g$ is given by

$$
\begin{matrix}
&& h^{0,1} &&\\
& h^{1,0} & & h^{1,1} &\\
&& h^{2,1} &&
\end{matrix}
$$

with $h^{0,1} = h^{1,0} = g = 1$ and $h^{1,1} = 2g - 2 = 0$. Therefore, the Hodge diamond of $X$ is

$$
\begin{matrix}
&& 1 &&\\
& 1 & & 0 &\\
&& 1 &&
\end{matrix}
$$

Now, we can compute the Euler characteristic of $X$ using the formula we proved:

$$\chi(X) = \sum_{p=0}^{1}(-1)^p h^{p,p} = h^{0,0} - h^{1,1} = 1 - 0 = 1.$$
